titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.25 (14 June-21 June 1660)]

titleStmt.title: Mercurius publicus: comprising the sum of forraign intelligence ...[no.25 (14 June-21 June 1660)]
Mercurius publicus (London, England : 1659)
titleStmt.author: Muddiman, Henry, fl.1659-1666, editor.
Dury, Giles editor.
Newcomb, Thomas, d. 1681 or 2, publisher.

biblFull.extent: v. Began with numb. 1 (29 Dec. 1659-5 Jan. 1660); ceased with numb. 33 (13-20 Aug. 1663).

notesStmt.note: Subtitle varies: 1660, "... comprising the sum of forraign intelligence"; 1661-1663, "... comprising the sum of all affairs now in agitation."
By Henry Muddiman and Giles Dury. Cf. Nelson and Seccombe.
Printed variously by: John Macock, Thomas Newcomb, Richard Hodgkinson, D. Maxwell, Peter Lillicrap, James Cottrell.
Numb. 43 (18-25 Oct. 1660) is a second copy of The Parliamentary intelligencer for those dates, mistakenly titled Mercurius publicus.
Thomason collection does not have complete run.
Reels listed in chronological order of serial publication; holdings dispersed throughout collection.
Reproduction of the originals in the British Library.
Enumeration begins again at numb. 1 annually.
No issue numbered 52 in 1660, no issue numbered 44 in 1661; chronology is continuous.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Numb. 25. Mercurius Publicus: COMPRISING The Sum of Forraign Intelligence; WITH The Affairs now in Agitation in England, Scotland, and Ireland. For Information of the People. Publi≈øhed by Order of the Council of State. From Thur≈øday June 14 to Thur≈øday June 21. 1660.

div.p: DOn Emanuel Caraffa, Field-Mar≈øhal-General of the N ‚Ä¢ apolitan foot, hath mu≈øtered his men this week, in order to ≈øhip them away upon the Prince of Monto≈øarchio, being de≈øigned for the ≈øervice again≈øt Portugal. In con≈øequence of the Peace betwixt the two Crowns, our Viceroy hath ≈øet at liberty all the French that were pri≈øonere of War in ≈øeveral places of this Kingdome, and hath ≈øo favourably u≈øed them, that they have rea≈øon to be very well ≈øatisfied of him.
The 15 in≈øtant, the Pope came again hither from Ca≈øtel Gandolphe, and the next day, being the White-Sunday, he held Chappel at the Quirinal, where the Ma≈øs was ≈øung by the Cardinal Barbarin.

div.head: Venice the ≈øame date.
div.p: By the Letters from our Fleet, we have no confirmation of the reducing of the I≈øle of Negroponte, but they ≈øay only that Seignior Bembo, the General of Candia, hath ≈øent thither four ≈øhips, with ≈øome Companies of Souldiers, to ha≈øten the taking of the ≈øame. A great quantity of Bisket is preparing here for the forces that are to pa≈øs from Provence into Candia for the ≈øervice of the Republick.

div.head: Vienna the ≈øame date.
div.p:
The Emperour having received the confirmation from his Mini≈øters in Pru≈ø≈øia, of the ≈øub≈øcribing of the Treaty of Oliva, hath ≈øent advice thereof to all the Princes of the Empire. He hath likewi≈øe di≈øpatched two Expre≈ø≈øes, the one to the Grand Seignior, and the other to the Ba≈øhaw of Offen, to complain of the ho≈øtilities exerci≈øed by the Turks in Hungary, enquire into their de≈øign, and declare unto the ≈øaid Ba≈øhaw, that unle≈øs he will ≈øpeedily draw off his Army, his Imperial Maje≈øty will endeavour with his own to force him out. In the mean while, the Turks continuing their deva≈øtations in the Country, order hath been ≈øent to the General of the Imperial Forces quartered about Ca≈ø≈øubia, to be ready to march, and in ca≈øe of need to joyn with Prince Ragotzky, to whom a Gentleman hath been al≈øo ≈øent, to con ‚Ä¢ ult with him about the means how to make
a ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtance to tho≈øe Infidels, and hinder them for the future to make any irruption into Hungary, whither the 500 hor≈øes lately come from Bohemia have been ≈øent, for the u≈øe of the Artillery.

The Pope is returned hither from Ca≈øtel Gandolphe in much better health, then he was gone from hence, yea, and is now better then he hath been in a long time. The French here are very much di≈øplea≈øed at the de≈øign which he ≈øhews to have to transfer the Chappel which the Colledge of the Cardinals holdeth every year in the Church of St. Ives, to that of the Sapience. The Queen of Sweden hath ≈øent already part of her Retinue, and is to follow ≈øhortly.

The Swedi≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners in Pru≈ø≈øia having ≈øent advice to the Governour of Wi≈ømar of the conclu≈øion of the Treaty of Oliva, he cau≈øed the ≈øame to be publi≈øhed in the ≈øaid Town, together with the ce≈ø≈øation of Arms, which is al≈øo very punctually ob≈øerved by the Imperiali≈øts; and yet General Wurts our Governour hath lately cau≈øed much cattel to be carried away by his men out of the lower Pomerania.

The Danes do ≈øtill very much annoy the Town of Tonningen, having yet lately burned two fire-hou≈øes thereabouts, becau≈øe the Inhabitants had with their Canon forced two Ships to retire, which General Eber≈øtein had cau≈øed to come neer the place to block it the ≈øtraighter; and unle≈øs the Commi≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ rie ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ Gluck≈øtad, where they are ≈øtill a≈ø≈øembled, do ≈øpeedily agree, it is feared they will come to greater ho≈øtilities.

The 26 of the la≈øt, the Governour of Wi≈ømat having ≈øhipped eight hundred men, they landed in the I≈øle of Fameren, which is divided from Hol≈øtein by a ≈ømall arm of Sea, and having cha≈øed ≈øome Dani≈øh hor≈øe, and forced the foot to run to their forts, they begun to plunder the Travellers; but an Imperiali≈øt Captain, with the Militia he could gather coming upon the Swedes, they retired in ≈øuch ha≈øte, that they could not ≈øecure their booty. It is feared that irruption may cau≈øe ≈øome ob≈øtruction in the Treaty between Swedeland and Denmark, the ratification whereof was expected.

A ≈øhip arrived this week from Lisbone, doth confirm the great preparations that are now making in Portugal again≈øt the Spaniards, and that they were working with great a≈ø≈øiduity about the fortifications of the ≈øaid Lisbone, as well as of Evora, Villa Vicio≈øa, and other places upon the ‚Ä¢ iver Guadiana.

Their Royal Highne≈ø≈øes have made choice of the Count of ‚Ä¢ a Trinite to go and complement the Duke and the Dutche≈øs of Parma, who as we heard from thence lately, were preparing to go and a≈ø≈øi≈øt at the Chri≈øtening of the Duke of Modena's Son, who was lately pre≈øent incognito with his brother Prince Almeric, to all the rejoycing made in the ≈øaid place of Parma. The forces which our Prince is to afford to the Republick of Venice, are to go march very ≈øuddenly, expecting only the Commi≈ø≈øary that is to come from thence with the nece≈ø≈øary ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rks and provi≈øions; but not above three troops of ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, each of fifty men, could be made up of the ten that were remaining on foot,
the re≈øt having been disbanded, upon their refu≈øal to ≈øerve in Candia, whither they were de≈øigned.

div.head: Ierpignan the ≈øame date.
div.p: Ye≈øterday, the Kings Order for the re≈øtitution of Bo≈øes, Cap de Quieres, Sean d' Urgel, and Belvore, arrived here. The ≈øubjects ≈øhall remain in the Bou≈ø≈øillon, where the Bi≈øhop of Orange, and Don Michel Salva ‚Ä¢ , the Spani≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners are expected, for the regulating of the limits of Cerdagne, and of the 35 villages that are to remain to the French.

The third Squadion of ≈øhips going to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Venetians, is ready to ≈øet forth to Sea, with the re≈øt of the ≈øupplies prepared for them, being of ≈øeven or eight hundred men. The Duke of Merco ‚Ä¢ ur hath ≈øent a Gentleman in the Kings name to Tunis, to demand the liberty of the French ≈ølaves there. He took occa≈øion for that, of favourable conjuncture of our Ships upon the Mediterranean, who do much alarum the ≈øaid Tunis, and it is thought that con≈øideration will induce tho≈øe Infidels to relea≈øe them ≈øooner then otherwi≈øe they would have done.

div.head:
Thur≈øday, Iune 14
at the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: The Hou≈øe this day read ≈øeveral private Petitions, and referred them to a Committee: They had likewi≈øe under their con≈øideration ≈øeveral things belonging to his Maje≈øtie Revenue.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: The Petitions of Bul≈øtrode Whitlock, and Sir Robert Reynolds, were this day read.
The whole Election for the Borough of Wilton in the County of Wilts, upon report made, was voted void, and new Writs were thereupon ordered to be i≈ø≈øued forth for a new Election there.

Re≈ø. That Daniel Axtell be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Indempnity and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Friday 15: At the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: This day the Lord Purbeck, by virtue of an Order of this Hou≈øe, was taken into the cu≈øtody of the Black Rod.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: The Hou≈øe ordered two Bills to be brought in for the continuing of the Cu≈øtomes and Exci≈øe for ≈øix moneths longer, to commence from Mid≈øummer next.

The Hou≈øe upon a former information of certain words pretended to be ≈øpoken by Col. White, in relation to the death of his late Maje≈øty of ble≈ø≈øed memory, referred the ≈øame to be examined by a Committee, and the examinations being this day reported,
It was re≈øolved, that the ≈øaid Col. White was not in the lea≈øt guilty of ≈øpeaking any ≈øuch words as were laid to his charge.

Mr. Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe that Alderman Pennington, one of his late Maje≈øties Tryers, had rendred him≈øelf to him according to his Maje≈øties Proclamation, and that he had put him into the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at Arms, till the plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe was further known; whereupon the Houie approved of it, and ordered him ≈øtill to remain in cu≈øtody.
The Que≈øtion being put whether Major General Butler ≈øhould be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the Act of Indempnity and Oblivioe, &c. it was carried in the negative.

Re≈øolved, that Iohn Blackwell, late Trea≈øurer of War, be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of pardon and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made to that purpo≈øe.

div.head: Saturday 16. At the Hou≈øe of Lords.
div.p: The Lord P ‚Ä¢ rbeck was this day brought to the Bar of the Hou≈øe by the B ‚Ä¢ k Rod, who ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h him ≈øtill in cu≈øtody.

div.head: At the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p: Re≈øolved, That his Maje≈øty be humbly moved to call in Milton's two books, and Iohn Goodwins, and order them to be burnt by the common hangman.
That the Attorney General do proceed again≈øt them by Indictment, or otherwi≈øe.

Mr. Speaker informed the Hou≈øe that Alderman Tichbourn, Colonel George Fleetwood, and Colonel Temple, three of the Judges of his late Maje≈øty, had rendred them≈øelves to him, and that he had put them into the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at arms, till the plea≈øure of the Hou≈øe was further known, whereupon the Hou≈øe approved of their commitment, and ordered them ≈øtill to remain in cu≈øtody.
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate of the Act of Indempnity and Oblivion, and read the Petition of Frances, wife of Iohn Lambert, whereupon they ordered, &c.

That Colonel Iohn Lambert be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the gener ‚Ä¢ l Act of Pardon and Oblivion, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties, and forfeitures, not extending to life, as ≈øhall be inflicted on him by an Act hereafter to be made to that purpo≈øe.

The Que≈øtion being put, whether Alderman Chri≈øtopher Pack ≈øhould be of the twenty to be excepted, &c. It was ordered, That Alderman Chri≈øtopher Pack be one of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Pardon.
The like Order was made concerning Serjeant R ‚Ä¢ . Keeble, that he be one of the twenty, &c.

div.head: Whitehall, Friday 15.
div.p:
His Maje≈øty ≈øet forth a Proclamation for recalling all Commi≈ø≈øions at Sea granted out by his Maje≈øty, or his Royal Brother, the Duke of York, before the fir≈øt of May la≈øt, willing and commanding every of them to forbear further execution of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øions, upon pain of ≈øuch puni≈øhments as may legally be inflicted on pyrates; and likewi≈øe requiring all his Subjects imployed
in Sea affairs by any forreign Prince, to repair home to his Maje≈øties ≈øervice.

The ≈øame day the heads of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, with ≈øeveral Doctors in ‚Ä¢ rler, and many Ma≈øters of Art, were conducted by the Earl of Southampton (who by rea≈øon of the indi≈øpo≈øition of health of the Marque≈øs of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , did that civility for them) and the B ‚Ä¢ rge ‚Ä¢ ≈øes ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ving in Parliament for the Univer≈øity to his Maje≈øty, where Doctor Conaught the Vice-Chancellor made a ≈øpeech to his Maje≈øty, after which they had all the honor to ki≈øs his Maje≈øties hand.

This day al≈øo the Town of King≈øton upon H ‚Ä¢ ll, who as they have not yeilded to any in expre≈ø≈øing and ≈øole ‚Ä¢ miz ‚Ä¢ ng among them≈øelves in the be≈øt manner their joy upon the ≈øeveral o ‚Ä¢ ca≈øions of the happy Return, and the proclaiming of his Maje≈øty, ≈øo for a further demon≈øtration of their loyalty, duty, and affection to his Maje≈øty, did this d ‚Ä¢ y by the hand of their Members in Parliament, and ≈øome others, per≈øons of Quality in that place, who had the honor to be introduced by his Excellency, pre≈øent to his Maje≈øty their humble add ‚Ä¢ e≈ø ‚Ä¢ , in congratulation of that gracious providence by which his Maje≈øty hath been re≈øtored to his people; and therewith they tendered al≈øo under the Seal of their Corporation, a Relea≈øe of certain Fee-farms there, which being in the≈øe times expo≈øed to ≈øale, they had redeemed out of o ‚Ä¢ her hands fo ‚Ä¢ twelve hundred pounds, and now joyfu ‚Ä¢ ly re≈øto ‚Ä¢ ed them to his Maje≈øty, both which were by his Maje≈øty gratiou≈øly received, and with particular expre≈ø≈øions of favour to the ≈øaid Town.

On Saturday the 16. his ≈øacred Maje≈øty accompanied by his two Royal Brothers, the D ‚Ä¢ ke of York, and D ‚Ä¢ ke of Gloce≈øter, as al≈øo ≈øeveral of the Nobility and Gentry was plea≈øed to ≈øup with the Lord Mayor of London at his hou≈øe. Before ≈øupper the Lord Mayor brought to his Maje≈øty a napkin dipt in Ro≈øe-water, and offered it kneeling, with which when his Maje≈øty had wip'd his hands, he ≈øat down at a Table rai≈øed by an a≈øcent, the Duke of York on his right hand, and the D ‚Ä¢ ke of Gloce≈øter on his left; they were ≈øerved with three ≈øeveral cour≈øes, at each cour≈øe the Table-cloth was ≈øhifted, and at every di≈øh which his Maje≈øty, or the Dukes ca≈øted, the napkins. A ‚Ä¢ another table in the ≈øame room ≈øat hare his Excellency the Lord General, the Duke of Buckingham, the Marque≈øs of O ‚Ä¢ mond, the Earl of Oxford, Earl of Norwich, Earl of Saint A ‚Ä¢ bans Lord De la VVare, Lord Sands Lord Bercley, and ≈øeveral other of the Nobility, with Knights and Gentlemen of great quality Sir John Robin≈øon, A ‚Ä¢ derman of London, began an health to his Maje≈øty, which was pledged by all at the Table ≈øtanding. His Maje≈øty was all the while entertained with variety of m ‚Ä¢ ≈øick, and one that repre≈øented a Countryman, with whom his Maje≈øty „Äà‚óä„Äâ to be well plea≈øed. His Maje≈øty „Äà‚óä„Äâ the honor of Knighthood on Alderman John Lawrence, and Mr. Cutler, two loyal Citizens; the two fi ‚Ä¢ that his Maje≈øty be≈øtowed that honour on in the City of London; on the latter, as a memorial of his particular favour, he was plea≈øed to be≈øtow his own Sword.

div.head: Wedne≈øday, June 30 1660. The Manner of the Univer≈øity of Oxford's Addre≈øs to His Maje≈øty.
div.p: The Vice-Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxford came to London with divers Doctors, Bachelers of Divinity, the Proctors and Ma≈øters of Arts, with their publick Officers to pre≈øent ≈øolemnly the ≈øervice of that Univer≈øity unto the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.

They fir≈øt agreed to meet the next day in the Temple-Church, about 4. a clock, whence they went orderly in rank by two and two according to their Seniority to E≈ø≈øex Hou≈øe, to wait on the mo≈øt Noble Marquis of Hertford Chancellor of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity; where order was taken for the manadgement of the Addre≈øs that was to be made to his Maje≈øty on the Friday. The place thought fitte≈øt to put on Academical Hab ‚Ä¢ s was Derby Hou≈øe, propounded and procured by Dr. Lewis Du Moulin, where about three of the clock the ≈øaid Friday met the per≈øons here under named, who went in order with the ≈øix Squires and Yeomen Bedels of that Univer≈øity, having their ≈øtaves and three of them wearing their Golden Chains, and the Verger before them.
Dr. John Conant Rector of Exeter Colledg, Vice-Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, and Doctor of the Chaire or Regius profe≈ø≈øor of Theologia there.

Then two Honorable Members of Parliament were in their Cloaks, one at the right hand the other at the left hand of the Vice-Chancellor, viz. Dr. Thomas Clayton Doctor of the Chair or Regius Profe≈ø≈øor Medicinae, and Dr. John Mills Doctor of the Civil Law and one of the Collegiat Prebendaries of Chri≈øt-Church, being both Burge≈ø≈øes ≈øerving in Parliament for the Univer≈øity of Oxford.
Dr. Edmond Staunton Pre≈øident of Corpus Chri≈øti Colledge.
Dr. Edward Reynolds one of his Maje≈øties Chaplains and Dean of Chri≈øt-Church.
Dr. Henry Wilkin≈øon Senior, one of the Collegiat Prebenbaries at Chri≈øt-Church, and publick profe≈ø≈øor of Divinity for the Lady Margaret in Oxford.
Dr. Henry Langley one of the Collegiat Prebendaries of Chri≈øt-Church and Ma≈øter of Pembrook Colledge.
Dr. Michael Roberts ≈øometime Principal of Je≈øus Colledg ejected by Oliver Cromwel for his Loyalty to his Soveraign.
Dr. Henry Savadge Ma≈øter of Bailiol Colledge.
Dr Henry Wilkin≈øon Junior Principal of Magdalen Hall.
Dr. John Wallis, Sir H. Savills Profe≈ø≈øor of Arithmetick and Geometrie, and Cu≈øtos Archivorum of the Univer≈øity.
Dr. Seth Ward, one of Sir Henrys Profe≈ø≈øors of A≈øtronimie and Pre≈øident of Trinity Colledge.
All the≈øe Doctors in Divinity.

Next Dr. Lewis Du Moulin Doctor of Phy≈øick, Profe≈ø≈øor of Hi≈øtorie, Son of the famous Peter Du Moulin, Dr. Jonothan Godard Doctor of Phy≈øick, Warden of Morton Colledge, and publick Profe≈ø≈øor of Gre≈øham Colledge London.
Dr. Ralph Bathur≈øt Doctor of Phy≈øick and fellow of Trinity Colledg.
Dr. Lewis De Bourgongne of Lambermont Doctor of Phy≈øick.
Doctor Jo≈øhua Cro≈øs Doctor of the Civil Law, Fellow of Magdalen Colledge and publick Reader of the natural Philo≈øophie Lecture in Oxford.
Doctor Thomas Jones, Doctor of the Civil Law, and Fellow of Morton Colledge.
Doctor Thomas Jones Doctor of Phy≈øick Fellow of Magdalen Colledge.

Doctor „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Hodges ≈øometime Doctor of Phy≈øick Student of Chri≈øt Church.
All the Doctors above mentioned were in their Scarlet Robes, and di≈øtingui≈øhed by the ≈øeverall Schola≈øtical Habits belonging to their Faculty.

Afterwards both the Proctors of the Vniver≈øity, viz. Mr. Tanner Fellow of New Colledge, and Mr. Dod Student
of Chri≈øt Church, were in their black Gownes and Mini≈øters Hoods. Then followed the Batchelers of Divinity and Ma≈øters of Arts wearing their Gownes, Hoods, and Caps, according to their Degrees about the number of 100. more or le≈øs.

The≈øe came from Chanon-Row into Whitehall through the Garden, the Stone Gallery, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øed through the Court, the Guard Chamber, the Chamber of Pre≈øence, and ≈øo along to the long Gallery towards the Park Staires, where they made a ≈øtop for ≈øom con≈øiderable time untill they were fairly conducted into the Privy Gallery, having very cheerfull reception in their pa≈ø≈øing through the ≈øeverall Guards which were richly furni≈øhed with per≈øons of remarkable Gallantry.

A Chaire of State being placed in that ≈øame Gallery for his Maje≈øty, the Oxonians ≈øtaied not long there till they had notice of his Maje≈øties coming, the Right Honorable the Earle of Southampton ≈øupplying the Chancellors place; his Maje≈øty being entred, the Schollers bowed them≈øelves very low ≈øeverall times, and at due di≈øtance did kneel. When the Vice-Chancellor was ready to deliver his Speech kneeling, his Maje≈øty ≈øignified to him that he ≈øhould ≈øtand, in which po≈øture he did pronounce his Speech in Latin, his Maje≈øty ≈øtanding all the time, being attended by the Right Honorable the Marquis of Oxmond, the Earle of Manche≈øter, the Lord General Monck, and many other per≈øons of Honor. The ≈øub≈øtance of the Speech was to acquaint his Maje≈øty how highly plea≈øing to the Vniver≈øity his returne to his Kingdom was, and that that Vniver≈øity having for ≈øo long time been honored with his Maje≈øties pre≈øence, they could not but be more acquainted with his Princely vertues and ≈øo be more deeply ≈øen≈øible of their and the whole Kingdoms ≈øufferings in his ≈øo long ab≈øence. Next he humbly ≈øignified to his Maje≈øty that the eyes not only of the Vniver≈øity but of the whole Nation was towards him, wi≈øhing his Maje≈øty a long and happy Reigne, and ≈øo to govern, that the Land may be pre≈øerved and Religion e≈øtabli≈øhed. After the Speech ended
the Vice-Chancelor kneeling, pre≈øented his Maje≈øty with the Book of Ver≈øes of the Vniver≈øity of Oxford, Congratulatinp his Maje≈øties returne to Vs. ‚Ä¢ he Speech being ended his Maje≈øty thanked the Vice-Chancelor, adding that upon all occa≈øions he would protect the Vniver≈øities. Then was the Vice-Chancelor, the Doctors and all the ≈øaid Schollers admitted to have the honour to ki≈øs his Maje≈øties royal hand.

After the Kings departure from thence, the Oxon ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ s made ≈øom ≈øtay in the place in expectance of pre≈øenting their ≈øervices unto the mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, and when the Earle of Southampton brought notice that the ≈øaid Dukes were not then at Court, but were gon abroad to take the Aire, that Convocation of the Vniver≈øity retired them≈øelves in the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me Order from Whitehall to Derby Hou≈øe againe.

div.head: Adverti≈øements of Books newly Printed and Publi≈øhed.
div.p:
‚òûThere is newly come forth a very ≈øea≈øonable and u≈øeful Piece of Primative Devotion, in the Fea≈øts and Fa≈øts of the Church of England, con≈øi≈øting of Pro≈øe, Poems, Prayers, and Sculptures on the ≈øeveral Occa≈øions; Dedicated to the King. By Edward Sparke B. D. And are to be ≈øould ready bound or in Quires, by Octavian Pul ‚Ä¢ en at the Ro≈øe, or Tho: Driver at the Bi≈øhops-head in St Pauls Church Yard; as al≈øo by Edward Eccle≈øtone, right again≈øt the Red Cro≈øs in Sea-Cole-Lane, and by John H ‚Ä¢
m ‚Ä¢ r≈øham in Jeru≈øalem Court in Fleet≈øtreet, the ≈øaid Books being five ≈øhillings in Quires ‚Ä¢ and but 500 of them.

The Accompli≈øht Courtier: Con≈øi≈øting of In≈øtitutions and Examples, by which Courtiers and Officers of State may ≈øquare their T ‚Ä¢ an≈øactions prudently, and in good order and method. By H. W. Gen ‚Ä¢ .
ARNALDO, or, The Injured Lover. An excellent new Romance, tran≈ølated by T Sa ‚Ä¢ usbury Gent.

The Learned man defended and reform'd. A Di ‚Ä¢ cour≈øe of ≈øingular politene≈øs and elocur ‚Ä¢ on; and is in oppo≈øition to the many enemies Learning meets with, e≈øpecially Ignorance and Vice. Written by P. Bartolus, and made Engli≈øh by T. Salusbury Gent.
The≈øe three are ≈øold by Tho. Dring at the George neer S. Dun≈øtans Church in Fleet≈øtreet.

Samuel in Sackcloth: Or, a Sermon a≈ø≈øaying to re≈øtrain our Bitter Animo≈øities, and commending a Spirit of Moderation, and a right Con≈øtitution of Soul and Behaviour towards our Brethren. Upon 1 Sam. 15.35. By S S. Sold by Henry Mortlock at the Phenix in S. Pauls Churchyard.

div.head: Adverti≈øements.
div.p:
GEntlemen, You are de≈øired to take notice, That Mr. Theophilus Buckworth who for ≈øome years pa≈øt permitted, and gave directions to his Brother Mr. Edmond Buckworth, to make and expo≈øe to ≈øale for the publick good, tho≈øe ≈øo famous Lozanges or Pectorals approved for the cure or Con≈øump ‚Ä¢ ions, Coughs, Catarrhs, A≈øthma's, Hoar≈øne≈øs, Strongne≈øs of Breath, Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s in general, Di≈øea≈øes incident to the Lungs, and a ≈øoveraign Antidote again≈øt the Plague, and al≈øo her contagious Di≈øea≈øes, and ob≈øtructions of the Stomach, doth now him≈øelf (being the Au ‚Ä¢ hor and fir≈øt co ‚Ä¢ pou ‚Ä¢ der of them) make them at his Hou≈øe on M ‚Ä¢ le end G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ en And for more conveniency of the p ‚Ä¢ ople, con≈øtan ‚Ä¢ ly leaveth th ‚Ä¢ m ≈øe ‚Ä¢ led up with his Coat of Arms on the Papers with Mr. Richard ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wades (as formerly) at the ≈øign of the White Lion near the Little North door of Pauls Church, Mr Henry Sei ‚Ä¢ e over again≈øt Dun≈øtan Church in Fleet≈øtreet, Mr William Milward

We ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ minste ‚Ä¢
Hall Gate, Mr. John Place at Furnivals-Inn Gate in H ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ orn, and Mr Robert H ‚Ä¢ rn at the Turks head near the entrance of the Royal Exchange Book≈øellers, and no others.

p.hi: This is publi≈øhed to prevent the de≈øigns of divers pretenders who counterfeit the ≈øaid Lozenges to the di≈øparagement of the ≈øaid Gentleman, and great abu≈øe of the people.

div.p: THe≈øe Books following, with ≈øeveral others, w ‚Ä¢ re la ‚Ä¢ ely lo≈øt from Mr. Tho. A≈øhton, having his name in them, viz. Grotius his Ann ‚Ä¢ tations on the Bible, three volum ‚Ä¢ s, Latine, Cambdens Britannia, Engli≈øh. Ma ‚Ä¢ lorat o ‚Ä¢ par ‚Ä¢ of the New Te≈øtament, Latine. Thucidides his Hi≈øt ‚Ä¢ ry, E ‚Ä¢ gli≈øhed by H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Bacons Advancement to Learning, Engli≈øh. Flacii Clavis Scripturae, Lat. Ba≈øil. Whateley on Gene≈øis, Engl. London. Willets Hexapla on Gene≈øis, Eng. London. Shute's Sarah & Hagar, Eng. Lond. Dr. Clarks Sermons, Eng. Daniels Engli≈øh Hi≈øtory, Eng. all in Folio. Pi≈øcator on the New Te≈øtament, 4o. 2 volumes. The Septuagints Old Te≈øtament, 8o. French Bible, 8o. Tombs Works, &c. If any one ≈øhall give notice of all, or any of them, at the Eagle and child in the Strand, the party ≈øhall be thankfully rewarded for his pains.

A White Mare ≈øomewhat fleabitten, betwixt 14. and 15 hands high, with a brand-mark two I.I. in pitch, was taken away on Tue≈øday night from about Holloway. The per≈øon ≈øu≈øpected to take her away, was one Willam Dua, of a ruddy color, flaxen hair, middle-≈øiz'd, of about twenty years of age. If any one bring in the Mare, or Man, to the Red Hart in Fetter-lane, or to the White Lion in I≈ølington, he ≈øhall receive Twenty ≈øhilling ‚Ä¢ for his pains.

J∆≤ne 17. Strayed out of the grounds near the Hor≈øe ferry in We≈øtmin≈øter in the County of Middle≈øex, one white gray Gelding about 14 hands high, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhort bob-tall, mo≈øt of his mane ≈øhorn, about 8 years old, both pa ‚Ä¢ e and trot. Who≈øo ≈øhall give notice of him to Sir Robert Pye Knight, at his hou≈øe in S. Stevens Court neer the New Palace in VVe≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, ≈øhall be well rewarded for their pains.

This day was publi≈øhed a Proclamation of his Maje≈øties gracious pardon in pur≈øuance of his Maje≈øties former Declaration, declaring that his Maje≈øty doth graciou≈øly accept of the Addre≈øs of the Hou≈øe of Commons, wherein th ‚Ä¢ y
did in behalf of them≈øelves, and every of them, and all the Commons of England, lay hold upon his Maje≈øties free and general pardon, as it was granted in his Maj ‚Ä¢ ≈øties Letters and Declaration, (excepting onely ≈øuch a ‚Ä¢ ≈øhould be excepted by Parliament) and will willingly and freely give his Royal A≈ø≈øent to the Act of general pardon when pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty by the two Hou≈øes, leaving it to his Subjects to ≈øue our part ‚Ä¢ cular pardons in ≈øuch manner as they ≈øhall think fit; and to that purpo≈øe, appointing the Secretaries of Sta ‚Ä¢ e to pre≈øent War arts for his Maje≈øties Signature directing the Attorney General to prep ‚Ä¢ re B ‚Ä¢ lls for pa ‚Ä¢ ng pardons to ≈øuch as de≈øire the ≈øame: In the i≈ø≈øui ‚Ä¢ g out of which, ‚Ä¢ are ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ aken that no pardon pa≈øs to any of the no oa ‚Ä¢ ous Off ‚Ä¢ nders excepted by Pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iament.
Sir Henry Mildmay pe ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ ioned „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , that they would be plea≈øed to di≈øpence wi ‚Ä¢ h his commitment to the Tower: whereupon it was ordered; that he be committed to the Serjeant at Arms.
A Committee was ‚Ä¢ ppointed to con≈øider of the Impropriations late in the hand of the Tru≈øt ‚Ä¢ es for maintenance of Mini≈øters, and what is fit to be done in that aff ‚Ä¢ ir.

Mr. Speak ra ‚Ä¢ quai ‚Ä¢ ted the Hou≈øe, that Sir John Bourchier, Col. Owen R ‚Ä¢ e, and Col. Robert Lilburn, three of the Judges of his late Maje≈øty, had rendred them≈øelves to him, and that he had put them into the cu≈øtody of the Serjeant at Arms: which the Hou≈øe approved of.

His Maje≈øty ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øage in writing to the Hou≈øe, to de≈øire them to ha≈øten the Bill of indempnity: whereupon they re≈øu ‚Ä¢ ed the debate, and re≈øolved, That
Charles Fleetwood,
John Pyne,
Maj. Creed,
John Goodwin,
Ri. Dean,
Philip Nye,
Col. Cobbet,
be of the twenty to be excepted out of the general Act of Pardon and Indempnity, to ≈øuffer ≈øuch pains, penalties and forfeitures, not extending to li ‚Ä¢ e, as ≈øhould be inflicted on them, by an Act hereafter to be made for that purpo≈øe.
Re≈øolved, That William Hulet and Hugh Peters be excepted out of the general Act of Pardon and Oblivion.

The Speaker made a report to the Hou≈øe, That Adrian Scroop, Augu≈øtine G ‚Ä¢ rla ‚Ä¢ d, Colonel Harvy and Mr. Smith, who ≈øate as Judges upon the late King's Maje≈øty, had according to the Proclamation rendred them≈øelves to „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and that he had committed them to the Sergeant at Armes: Of which the Hou≈øe approved.

The Hou≈øe ordered, that thanks be given to the Lord Montague, K ‚Ä¢ ight of the mo≈øt No ‚Ä¢ le Order of the Garter, for the Eminent ≈øervices which he hath perf ‚Ä¢ rmed to his Maje≈øty and the Kingdome.
O ‚Ä¢ ered, that Colonel John Downs, one of the King's Judges, ≈øei≈øed upon by Ord ‚Ä¢ r from the General, be committed to the Sergeant at Arms.
The Hou≈øe re≈øumed the debate o ‚Ä¢ the Bill of Pardon and Oblivion, and orde ‚Ä¢ ed it to be recommitted, and br ‚Ä¢ ught in again ‚Ä¢ tomorrow morning.
A Bill ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ a longer c ‚Ä¢ ntinu ‚Ä¢ tion of Cu≈øtoms and ‚Ä¢ xci≈øe, w ‚Ä¢ s read this day the ≈øecond time; and upon the deba ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ was recommitted.

O ‚Ä¢ dered, That our age and P ‚Ä¢ unda ‚Ä¢ e be g ‚Ä¢ anted to his M ‚Ä¢ e≈øty during his ‚Ä¢ e, and it i ‚Ä¢ referred to a Commit ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ to pr ‚Ä¢ pare a B ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ accordingly, and, to con≈øider how it m ‚Ä¢ y be di≈øpo≈øed at pre≈øent till the Bill be d ‚Ä¢ ≈øpatched, and the Book of Rates agreed.
A Petition of the Marchants Trading to Spaine, was referred to a Committee.

Mr. Robert Rolles who ≈øerved in Parliament for the Borough of Kellyton in Cornwall, being decea≈øed, the Hou≈øe ordered Writs to be i≈ø≈øued for a new Election of a member to ≈øerve in Parliament for that Borough.
A Report being made from the Committee for Priviledges and Elections, concerning Truro in Oornwal, it was re≈øolved that Mr. Bo≈øcowen is duly elected to ≈øerve in Parliament for that place.
The Bill for continuance of the Cu≈øtom and Exci≈øe was read this day, and referred to a Committee who are to con≈øider the qualifications of Officers to be imployed in the Exci≈øe.

Re≈øolved, That the payment of Publique Debts contracted from the 5. of Decem ‚Ä¢ er 16 ‚Ä¢ 8, till the 22. of February 1659. other then tho≈øe of the Army and Navy, be ≈øtopp'd till ‚Ä¢ urther Order.
Re≈øolved, That 10000 l. be charged upon the A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment of 700000 l. per men≈ø. to be paid ‚Ä¢ o ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons as the Queens Maje≈øty ≈øhall appoint for her p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øent ≈øupply.
The Bill for Tunnage and Poundage was this day repotted, twice read, and referred to a grand Committee.
The Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe, that Sir Hard ‚Ä¢ e≈øs Waller had rendred him≈øelf to him; whereupon it was ordered that the Sergeant at Arms take him into cu≈øtody.

The Speaker informed the Hou≈øe, that he was petitioned by a relation of Col. Dixwells, that he being ≈øick, and therefore not able to render him≈øelf by the time limited in the Proclamation, that he might not lo≈øe the benefit thereof; whereupon it was ordered, that upon the ≈øurrendring of him≈øelf he ≈øhould not lo≈øe the benefit of the Proclamation.
The Speaker acquainted the Hou≈øe, that upon the ≈øurrender of Henry Martin one of the Judges of the late King, he had committed him to the Serjeant at Arms, which the Hou≈øe approved of.
Re≈øolved, That Adrian Scroop be di≈øcharged from his Commitment, upon his engagement to appear when required thereunto.

div.head: From his Excellenies Quarters at the Cockpit.
div.p: A Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal of England impowered Dr. Mills Judge Advocate to ≈øee that the oath of Allegiance and Supremacy be taken by all the Officers and Soldiers about London before him, as al≈øo to impower Ralph King to ≈øee the ≈øame done by the Officers and Soldiers of the Army about Dublin.

On Monday a L ‚Ä¢ tter from Liev ‚Ä¢ . Colonel Richard Yardley to an Officer of the ‚Ä¢ rmy was Communicated to his Excellency, conteining the ≈øolemnity of Proclaiming his Maje≈øty in the I≈øle of Jer≈øey.

His Excellency bei ‚Ä¢ g informed that his ≈øavors j ‚Ä¢ ≈øtly be≈øtowed upon Dougall Mack Pher≈øon a Scotch G ‚Ä¢ ntleman, was by ≈øome that envied the merit of that per≈øon endeavoured to be repre≈øented as the reward of ≈øome Intelligence that ≈øhould b ‚Ä¢ given to his Excellency by him, or his means, did for the ju≈øt vindica ‚Ä¢ on of the ‚Ä¢ aid Dougall Mack Pher≈øon and to ≈øtop the mouthes of ≈øuch ≈ølauderous people, give a C ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ ificate under his hand and Seal.
On Tue≈øday, Col. Faggs Regiment, by his Excellencies orders, drew out in S. Georges fields, and there took the Oath of Allegiance and Supremacy.
His Excellency is by the Corporation of Trinity-Hou≈øe cho≈øen Ma≈øter, and hath appointed Sir William Batten to be Deputy.

His Excellency hath lately di≈øpo≈øed ≈øeveral ‚Ä¢ ommands in the Army, and g ‚Ä¢ ve ‚Ä¢ the≈øe ‚Ä¢ ommi≈ø≈øions following, viz. To the Earl of Northampton to be „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the ‚Ä¢ egiment late Col. Lenthals, and to Sir Tho. Sards to be his Lieutenant c ‚Ä¢ l.
To the Lord Fall ‚Ä¢ land to be Colonel of the Regiment late Col. Sanders, and to Ble ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Morgan to be Major.
To Maj ‚Ä¢ r Jeremiah Ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ on to be Major in the place of Major Scot.
To Major Harley to be Major in≈øtead of Major Izod of Sir Anthony A≈øhley‚ñ™ Co ‚Ä¢ pers Regiment.

div.head: Whitehal 20.
div.p: The Lord Mayor the Aldermen, and the Common Council of the City of London went on Monday l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt to Whitehal, and being conducted up to the matted Gallery, his Maje≈øty came to them, where the common Serjeant made a Speech to his Maje≈øty, repre≈øenting the affection of the City to him, and their humble de≈øire that his Maje≈øty would be plea≈øed to honor them wi ‚Ä¢ h his company at Dinner, which his Maje≈øty was graciou≈øly plea≈øed to accept of, and g ‚Ä¢ ve to each of them the honor of ki≈ø≈øing his Maje≈øties hand. The day appointed for that entertainment, is Thur≈øday the Fifth of July next.

The ≈øame day, Sir James Barry accompanied by the Commi≈ø≈øioners from Ireland, delivered him≈ø ‚Ä¢ lf in a Sp ‚Ä¢ ech to his ‚Ä¢ aje≈øty, wherein he expre≈ø≈øed the great ≈øo ‚Ä¢ row and joy of that ‚Ä¢ ation: Their ≈øorrow for the Sufferings and Murder of h ‚Ä¢ s ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ aj ‚Ä¢ ≈øty of Ble≈ø≈øed Memory, and their joy for his Maje≈øties happy re≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ion; a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uring his Maje≈øty of the con≈øtant Loyalty of his Subjects in Ireland, of which he acquainted his Maje≈øty, that the Lord Broghil, Sir Charls Coote, and Sir Theophilus Jon ‚Ä¢ s had given ≈øuch large Te≈øtimonies by their eminent Services for his Maje≈øty. At the clau≈øe of the Speech he pre≈øented his ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ e≈øt ‚Ä¢ with a B ‚Ä¢ ll of 20000 l. accepted by Alderman Thomas Viner, formerly orde ‚Ä¢ ed to be pre≈ø ‚Ä¢ nted to his Maje≈øty by the ≈øaid Convention. His Maje≈øty accepted of it gave them thank ‚Ä¢ for the ‚Ä¢ Loyalty, and an a≈ø≈øurance of his Maje≈øties favor to that Nation, a ‚Ä¢ ter which, they all ki≈ø≈øed his Maje≈øties hand.

The ≈øame day, the Mini≈øters and Elders of the French, Dutch and Italian Churches, waited upon his Maje≈øty at Whitehall. Mr. Stoupe, the Mini≈øter of the French Church, made a Speech, to which his Maje≈øty made a gracious an≈øwer, and gave them a≈ø≈øurance of his Royal protection. The next day, the ≈øaid Churches waited up ‚Ä¢ n the Dukes of Y ‚Ä¢ rk and Gloce≈øter, who received them with many expre≈ø≈øions of their affection.
Tue≈øday la≈øt, the Earl of Pembroke gave a noble Entertainment to his Maje≈øty‚ñ™ the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, at B ‚Ä¢ inards ca≈øtle.

On Tue≈øday l ‚Ä¢ ≈øt, b ‚Ä¢ ing the 19. of this moneth, Major Hagedot who brought by Mr John Carew, one of tho≈øe that ≈øate in Judgment upon King Charls the Fir≈øt, deliver'd him by old ‚Ä¢ r of the Speaker to the S ‚Ä¢ rjeant at Arms
